questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of diarrhea, bloating, nausea, and vomiting. He describes his stool as soft, frothy, and greasy. He denies seeing blood in the stool. He went on a hiking trip last week and drank fresh water from the stream. Three months ago, he was on vacation with his family for 2 weeks in Brazil, where he tried many traditional dishes. He also had watery diarrhea and stomach cramping for 3 days during his visit there. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. The patient appears dehydrated. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and diffuse abdominal tenderness. Microscopy of the stool reveals cysts. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin can be used to treat traveler's diarrhea caused by enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli endemic in many tropical countries. This patient visited Brazil 3 months ago and might have contracted traveler's diarrhea (watery diarrhea) during that time, which resolved without further treatment. At this time, however, the patient most likely has giardiasis, which ciprofloxacin is not effective against.

B) CORRECT:

Giardiasis is the most common parasitic cause of diarrhea in the US. It is caused by Giardia lamblia, which can be transmitted by drinking contaminated untreated water (natural springs, streams). Tinidazole is an antibiotic that is effective against anaerobes and protozoa, and it is commonly used for the treatment of giardiasis. This treatment option has been shown to have fewer side effects, higher cure rates, and a lower antibiotic resistance rate than metronidazole, which is also frequently used to treat giardiasis in the US. Management also includes supportive care (e.g., hydration, electrolyte imbalance correction).

C) INCORRECT:

TMP/SMX is used for maintenance therapy in Whipple disease, which may also present with malabsorption and greasy stools. However, there are usually also extraintestinal symptoms such as migratory arthritis, lymphadenopathy, and/or neurologic deficits. Moreover, Whipple disease would not present with cysts in a stool sample. TMP/SMX is not effective against giardiasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral vancomycin is the first-line therapy for Clostridioides difficile infection, which may present with watery, rather than frothy and greasy, diarrhea. Moreover, C. difficile mainly causes infections in older patients (> 65 years) who have received treatment with an antibiotic like clindamycin or cephalosporin. This patient has no history of prior antibiotic treatment and most likely has giardiasis, which vancomycin is not effective against.

E) INCORRECT:

Supportive treatment is important in the context of diarrhea to replace fluid and electrolyte losses. However, this patient's diarrhea is caused by a parasite and therefore also demands causative treatment.
questions.hint: This patient's recent hiking trip, during which time he drank from a stream, and the detection of cysts in his stool make giardiasis the most likely diagnosis. This infection impairs absorption, which leads to greasy and frothy diarrhea.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of diarrhea, bloating, nausea, and vomiting for the past week. He describes his stool as greasy, frothy, and soft; it is not red or darkened. The patient went on a hiking trip in Brazil 3 weeks ago. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. The patient appears dehydrated. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and diffuse abdominal tenderness. Microscopy of the stool shows egg-shaped cysts with prominent two-layered cell wall and multiple nuclei. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral vancomycin is the second-line therapy for Clostridioides difficile infection, which may present with watery, rather than frothy, and greasy diarrhea. Moreover, C. difficile mainly causes infections in elderly patients (> 65 years) who have received treatment with an antibiotic like clindamycin or cephalosporin. This patient has no history of prior antibiotic treatment and most likely has giardiasis, against which vancomycin is not effective.

B) INCORRECT:

TMP-SMX is used for maintenance therapy in Whipple disease, which may also present with malabsorption and greasy stools. However, there are usually also extraintestinal symptoms such as migratory arthritis, lymphadenopathy, and/or neurologic deficits. Moreover, Whipple disease would not present with cysts in a stool sample. TMP-SMX is not effective against giardiasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin can be used to treat traveler's diarrhea caused by enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli endemic in many tropical countries. This patient visited Brazil 3 weeks ago and might have contracted traveler's diarrhea (watery diarrhea) during that time, which resolved without further treatment. At this time, however, the patient most likely has giardiasis, against which ciprofloxacin is not effective.

D) CORRECT:

Giardiasis is the most common parasitic cause of diarrhea in the US. It is caused by Giardia lamblia, which can be acquired from drinking untreated water (natural springs, streams). Metronidazole is an antibiotic that is effective against anaerobes and protozoa and is commonly used for giardiasis. Side effects include nausea and a metallic taste in the mouth. Tinidazole is an alternative antibiotic effective against Giardia that is often preferred as it has been shown to have fewer side effects, higher cure rates, and a lower antibiotic resistance rate than metronidazole.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a stool sample (wet mount; iodine stain)

An oval-shaped cyst with a prominent, double-layered wall is visible in the center of the image. The cytoplasm contains four nuclei, which are identifiable as spherical structures. It also contains an axostyle, a fibrillary structure from which the flagella of the trophozoite arises.

This is the typical appearance of a Giardia lamblia cyst, which is excreted in feces and responsible for the transmission of giardiasis through the ingestion of contaminated food or water.

E) INCORRECT:

Octreotide is used to relieve symptoms in patients with carcinoid tumors, which classically present with diarrhea, cutaneous flushing, and asthma-like attacks. This patient does not complain of any flushing or dyspnea.
questions.hint: The patient's recent hiking trip and the detection of cysts in his stool make giardiasis the most likely diagnosis. The infection impairs absorption, which leads to greasy and frothy diarrhea.

questions.text:
The response options for the next 2 items are the same. Select one answer for each item in the set.
For each patient with abdominal pain and diarrhea, select the most likely diagnosis.
A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of sudden-onset, acute periumbilical pain and diarrhea. During this time, he has had 4–6 bloody bowel movements per day. Six days ago he had a high fever, dizziness, and generalized muscle aches that lasted 1 day. The pain radiates to the right lower quadrant. He adopted a puppy from an animal shelter 1 week ago; the puppy has had several episodes of loose stools since it moved in with the patient. He has no history of recent travel. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 38.2 °C (100.8°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 128/78 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation; bowel sounds are increased. A stool specimen shows numerous leukocytes. A fecal occult blood test is positive.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute onset of systemic symptoms (fever, generalized muscle aches), abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea can be seen in shigellosis. However, Shigella is most commonly transmitted to humans by the consumption of contaminated food products (e.g., unpasteurized dairy products; unwashed raw vegetables; contaminated water), which is not consistent with this patient's history. Instead, this patient's infection is more likely due to contact with his recently adopted puppy, suggesting that a different pathogen is responsible for his diarrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

Enterohemorrhagic E.Coli (EHEC) infection can manifest with acute onset of systemic symptoms (fever, generalized muscle aches), abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea, all of which are seen here. EHEC is most commonly transmitted to humans by the consumption of contaminated food products (e.g., undercooked meats; unpasteurized dairy products; unwashed, raw vegetables). In contrast, this patient most likely acquired an infection from contact with the puppy he just adopted, suggesting that a different pathogen is responsible for his diarrhea.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's fever, generalized muscle aches, pseudoappendicitis (i.e., acute periumbilical pain radiating to the right lower quadrant), and bloody diarrhea after recent contact with a puppy should raise suspicion of campylobacteriosis. Campylobacter is transmitted by the fecal-oral route from the consumption of undercooked meat or unpasteurized milk products, or from direct contact with infected animals (most commonly dogs, cats, pigs, chickens) and their waste products. In this case, the patient most likely acquired campylobacteriosis from contact with the puppy he just adopted.

Bloody diarrhea indicates invasion of the gastrointestinal mucosa by the pathogen, which limits the potential causative organisms to Campylobacter, Salmonella, Shigella, enterohemorrhagic E. coli, enteroinvasive E. coli, Entamoeba Histolytica, and Yersinia. Presentation with pseudoappendicitis further narrows the differential down to Campylobacter and Yersinia.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute onset of systemic symptoms (fever, generalized muscle aches), abdominal pain, and inflammatory diarrhea are features of salmonellosis. Rather than inflammatory diarrhea, as seen here, salmonellosis is more commonly associated with watery diarrhea. Finally, Salmonella is transmitted by the consumption of contaminated food products (notably poultry, raw eggs, and unpasteurized dairy). This patient's infection is instead more likely due to contact with his recently adopted puppy.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute onset of fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea are features consistent with giardiasis. However, Giardia lamblia can be transmitted by the consumption of water from untreated sources (e.g., natural springs, mountain streams), rather than from contact with infected domestic animals. Additionally, giardiasis causes nonbloody, foul-smelling, greasy steatorrhea, and bloating, all of which are absent in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Acute onset of abdominal pain and diarrhea may be seen in Norovirus gastroenteritis, the most common cause of gastroenteritis in adults. However, Norovirus typically causes vomiting and nonbloody diarrhea, which is not seen here. Finally, Norovirus infection is most commonly associated with community outbreaks in nursing homes, hospitals, preschools, and cruise ships, especially during the winter months (i.e, November – March), rather than contact with infected domestic animals.

G) INCORRECT:

This 23-year-old patient presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea, both of which are seen in Rotavirus gastroenteritis. However, Rotavirus infection does not typically cause bloody diarrhea and would instead manifest with vomiting and watery diarrhea. Moreover, Rotavirus is most commonly transmitted by consumption of contaminated food/water, from person‑to‑person contact, contact with airborne droplets of vomitus, or contaminated surfaces. This patient recently adopted a puppy, making another pathogen the more likely cause of his infection.

H) INCORRECT:

Intestinal amebiasis can manifest with acute onset of systemic symptoms (fever, generalized muscle aches), abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea, all of which are seen here. However, this patient also presents with pseudoappendicitis (acute RLQ pain), which is not associated with intestinal amebiasis. Moreover, amebiasis is rare in the US and most commonly associated with ingesting food/water contaminated by amebic cysts, especially in tropical and subtropical regions (e.g., Mexico, Southeast Asia, India).

I) INCORRECT:

Patients infected with hookworms can present with abdominal pain and diarrhea, which may be associated with gross or occult bleeding. However, hookworm infections also commonly manifest with pruritus, erythema, maculopapular rash, and occasional serpiginous marks at the site of cutaneous entry, which are not seen here. Moreover, hookworm is most commonly transmitted from walking barefoot over contaminated sand/soil, which is not consistent with this patient's history.

J) INCORRECT:

Cryptosporidiosis can manifest with acute onset of systemic symptoms (fever, generalized muscle aches), abdominal pain, and diarrhea, all of which are seen in this patient. Infection with Cryptosporidium causes mild watery diarrhea in immunocompetent individuals and chronic, severe watery diarrhea in HIV patients with CD4 < 100/mm3. However, the diarrhea associated with cryptosporidiosis is nonbloody, rather than this patient's presentation with bloody diarrhea. Moreover, Cryptosporidium is transmitted through contact with an infected individual or consumption of contaminated water (e.g., drinking or swimming water) or food, rather than from contact with infected puppy.
questions.hint: All of these pathogens can cause acute diarrhea, but only one of them characteristically manifests with bloody, inflammatory diarrhea and is most commonly acquired through contact with an infected, domesticated animal.

questions.text:
For each patient with abdominal pain and diarrhea, select the most likely diagnosis.
A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of crampy abdominal pain and diarrhea. During this time, he has had 4–6 soft, voluminous, frothy bowel movements per day. Since the initial onset of his symptoms, he has also experienced fatigue, bloating, flatulence, and nausea. Nine days ago, he returned from a 2-week hiking trip in Colorado during which he drank water from a mountain stream. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 134/85 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation; bowel sounds are increased. A stool specimen shows no leukocytes. A fecal occult blood test is negative.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abdominal pain and diarrhea after the consumption of contaminated water can be seen in shigellosis. The diarrhea typical of Shigella infection, however, is profuse inflammatory and mucoid-bloody as opposed to this patient's frothy, nonbloody diarrhea. In addition, he lacks other key features of shigellosis such as high fever and tenesmus. Finally, this patient's bloating and flatulence are not consistent with shigellosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Abdominal pain and nonbloody diarrhea in an afebrile individual raise concern for enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) infection, the most common cause of traveler's diarrhea. However, ETEC is most commonly associated with travel to developing countries, which this patient has no history of. Additionally, bloating and frothy stools are not characteristic of ETEC.

C) INCORRECT:

Campylobacteriosis typically manifests with bloody, inflammatory diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain presenting as pseudoappendicitis or colitis, none of which is seen in this patient. Moreover, Campylobacter is transmitted by the fecal-oral route from the consumption of undercooked meat or unpasteurized milk products, and direct contact with infected animals (most commonly dogs, cats, pigs, chickens) and their waste products, which this patient has no history of.

D) INCORRECT:

Abdominal pain and watery diarrhea are symptoms seen in salmonellosis. Infection with Salmonella also commonly manifests with fever and severe vomiting, both of which are absent in this patient. Moreover, Salmonella is transmitted by the consumption of contaminated food products (notably poultry, raw eggs, and unpasteurized dairy), as opposed to drinking contaminated water from a mountain stream. Finally, this patient's bloating and flatulence are not consistent with salmonellosis, suggesting another etiology for his diarrhea.

E) CORRECT:

Frothy, nonbloody diarrhea with crampy abdominal pain and bloating in an afebrile individual with a history of drinking water from a mountain stream is consistent with giardiasis. Ingesting cysts from contaminated water sources (e.g., lakes, rivers, ponds, swimming pools) can cause infection with Giardia lamblia. Giardiasis impairs absorption within the gastrointestinal tract, leading to foul-smelling, greasy, and frothy diarrhea.

Common infectious causes of nonbloody diarrhea include bacteria (e.g., enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli, Clostridium perfringens, Clostridium difficile, Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus cereus, Vibrio cholera), parasites (e.g., Giardia, Cryptosporidium, Cyclospora), and viruses (Norovirus, Rotavirus). However, presentation with steatorrhea narrows the differential down to giardiasis.

F) INCORRECT:

Abdominal pain and nonbloody diarrhea in an afebrile individual can be seen in Norovirus gastroenteritis, the most common cause of gastroenteritis in adults. However, infection with Norovirus also commonly manifests with nausea and vomiting, which is not seen here. Moreover, this patient reports bloating and frothy diarrhea, both symptoms which are inconsistent with Norovirus gastroenteritis. Furthermore, Norovirus infection is most commonly associated with community outbreaks in nursing homes, hospitals, preschools, and cruise ships especially during the winter months (i..e, November – March), rather than drinking water from mountain streams.

G) INCORRECT:

This 25-year-old patient presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea, both of which are seen in Rotavirus gastroenteritis. However, Rotavirus infection also commonly manifests with fever and vomiting, which are not seen here. Moreover, this patient reports bloating and frothy diarrhea, both of which are inconsistent with Rotavirus infection. Furthermore, Rotavirus is transmitted through the fecal-oral route (e.g., by contact with hands, objects, food, water contaminated with the virus), rather than drinking water from mountain streams.

H) INCORRECT:

Intestinal amebiasis can also manifest with abdominal pain and diarrhea; however, diarrhea associated with intestinal amebiasis is bloody with mucus, unlike this patient's frothy, nonbloody diarrhea. In addition, intestinal amebiasis also commonly manifests with painful defecation, tenesmus, anorexia, and weight loss, which are not seen here. Moreover, amebiasis is rare in the US and most commonly associated with ingesting food or water contaminated by amebic cysts, especially in tropical and subtropical regions (e.g., Mexico, Southeast Asia, India).

I) INCORRECT:

Hookworm infection can manifest with abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, this patient lacks other characteristic features of infection such as pruritus, erythema, maculopapular rash, and serpiginous marks indicating the site of cutaneous entry. Moreover, hookworm is most commonly transmitted from walking barefoot over contaminated sand/soil, which is not consistent with this patient's history.

J) INCORRECT:

Abdominal pain and watery diarrhea can be seen in cryptosporidiosis. Infection with Cryptosporidium causes mild watery diarrhea in immunocompetent individuals or chronic, severe watery diarrhea in HIV patients with CD4 < 100/mm3. Cryptosporidium is transmitted through contact with an infected individual or consumption of contaminated water (e.g., drinking or swimming water) or food. While this patient develops watery diarrhea after drinking water from a mountain stream, he reports bloating and frothy diarrhea, both symptoms which are inconsistent with cryptosporidiosis.
questions.hint: All of these pathogens can cause acute diarrhea. But only one of them typically presents with frothy, nonbloody diarrhea and is commonly acquired through consumption of untreated water such as mountain streams.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of abdominal pain and diarrhea. The patient describes his stool as soft and voluminous but not bloody. He has not had a fever. He has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. He lives alone and has 3 pet cats. He is sexually active with multiple male and female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks two beers daily. Current medications include lisinopril and simvastatin. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 128/78 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and diffuse abdominal tenderness. A photomicrograph of a stool sample is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Campylobacter jejuni is a bacterial species that causes gastroenteritis, which typically manifests with abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, diarrhea associated with Campylobacter spp. is often bloody and accompanied by a high fever. Moreover, stool analysis would show curved, spiral-shaped bacilli, not cysts.

B) CORRECT:

Giardia lamblia is a protozoal species that causes giardiasis, which typically manifests with abdominal pain and diarrhea with voluminous, frothy, and fatty stools. Giardiasis can be transmitted by drinking recreational water (e.g., lakes, rivers) or by the fecal-oral route (e.g., food handlers, oral-anal sexual contact). Stool analysis shows cysts or flagellated trophozoites, both of which are multinucleated. The first-line treatment of giardiasis is with oral tinidazole.
Image Description:

Giardia lamblia is usually transmitted through the ingestion of cysts in contaminated drinking water or food, although fecal-oral transmission is also possible. In the gastrointestinal tract, Giardia lamblia cysts turn into trophozoites, which adhere to intestinal walls and rapidly multiply. While excreted trophozoites die, the excreted cysts are the infectious form of the pathogen and able to survive in most environments.

C) INCORRECT:

Toxoplasma gondii is a protozoal species that causes toxoplasmosis, which is transmitted through the ingestion of cysts found in raw meat or cat feces. Toxoplasmosis does not, however, cause diarrhea and abdominal pain; it typically manifests with mononucleosis-like symptoms (e.g., fever, cervical lymphadenopathy in immunocompetent individuals, and neurologic symptoms in immunocompromised individuals due to central nervous system involvement).

D) INCORRECT:

Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoal species that causes trichomoniasis, a sexually transmitted infection more common in individuals with high-risk sexual behavior (e.g., multiple sexual partners, not using condoms consistently). However, trichomoniasis is not associated with gastrointestinal symptoms. It is typically asymptomatic in men but can cause urethritis. In addition, Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated trophozoite and does not produce cysts.
Image Description:

Phase contrast photomicrograph of vaginal discharge (high magnification)

These parasites with flagella (blue overlay) are Trichomonas vaginalis, the causative pathogen of trichomonal vaginitis.

In the center, two squamous epithelial cells can be seen.

E) INCORRECT:

Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoal species that causes amebiasis, which typically manifests with abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, diarrhea associated with intestinal amebiasis is characteristically bloody and accompanied by painful defecation, tenesmus, anorexia, and weight loss, which are not seen here. In addition, while stool analysis may show multinucleated cysts, it would also typically show trophozoites with ingested erythrocytes.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a stool mount (trichrome stain; very high magnification)

A trophozoite with phagocytosed erythrocytes can be seen (dark circular inclusions, examples indicated by arrowheads).

F) INCORRECT:

Tropheryma whipplei is a bacterial species that causes Whipple disease, which is most common in men > 40 years of age and typically manifests with abdominal pain and diarrhea. Whipple disease is not, however, associated with cysts in the stool; diagnosis is based on the detection of bacterial DNA or PAS-positive foamy macrophages on histopathologic examination of an intestinal biopsy. In addition, Whipple disease is commonly associated with extraintestinal symptoms (e.g., arthralgia, weight loss, lymphadenopathy).

G) INCORRECT:

Enterobius vermicularis is a helminth that causes enterobiasis, which can cause abdominal pain. However, this condition more commonly results in anal pruritus, is primarily seen in children, and is not associated with diarrhea or cysts in the stool. The diagnosis of enterobiasis is made based on the visualization of ova and/or pinworms on a tape test.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a specimen prepared by applying cellulose tape to the anal region of a patient (very high magnification)

Eight transparent, elongated oval eggs, which are flattened asymmetrically on one side can be seen.

H) INCORRECT:

Shigella dysenteriae is a bacterial species that causes shigellosis, which typically manifests with abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, the diarrhea associated with shigellosis is characteristically bloody and not associated with cysts in the stool. In addition, this condition often causes high fevers, which this patient does not have.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a stool sample

Rod-shaped bacteria (examples in blue overlay) that also occasionally form short chains are visible. Erythrocytes (arrowheads indicate examples) and an inflammatory leukocytic exudate (examples in green overlay) can also be seen.

These findings are consistent with Shigella dysentery.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph shows an oval-shaped cyst with a prominent double-layered wall.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman who works at a child day-care facility reports a 10-day history of watery stools, abdominal cramping, bloating, anorexia, and a 2.3-kg weight loss. Motile trophozoites are evident on a stool sample.
Which one of the following treatments is indicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin and clarithromycin are not effective against Giardia.

B) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole, although never FDA-approved to treat giardiasis, was formerly a first-line agent but is now considered a second-line agent because of concerns about increasing resistance.

C) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin and clarithromycin are not effective against Giardia.

D) CORRECT:

Giardiasis is one of the most commonly diagnosed parasitic enteric infections. Fecal-oral transmission usually occurs in late summer and fall, typically in children aged 0 to 5 years and adults aged 31 to 40 years. Day-care contact, swimming in contaminated water, or ingestion of contaminated water (e.g., by hikers or campers) frequently precedes infection. Untreated patients can develop a potentially relapsing and remitting chronic diarrhea syndrome with steatorrhea and malabsorption. Trophozoites in the stool are diagnostic of Giardia, but a more sensitive test is Giardia antigen.

Tinidazole and nitazoxanide are recommended as first-line options for treating giardiasis. Tinidazole is FDA-approved for treatment of giardiasis in people ≥3 years old and nitazoxanide for those ≥12 months old.

Patients being treated for Giardia infection should be advised that temporary lactase deficiency is observed in 20% to 40% of patients in the weeks after infection and treatment.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first-line therapy for giardiasis is tinidazole or nitazoxanide.

E) INCORRECT:

Tinidazole and nitazoxanide are recommended as first-line options for treating giardiasis. Other alternative agents, such as albendazole, are also available.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man reports having persistent diarrhea (characterized by three loose, watery, nonbloody stools per day), abdominal bloating, and intermittent cramping for the past 6 weeks. He has also had intermittent headaches, which are new for him. The symptoms began shortly after he returned from a trip to rural Mexico. While there, he drank bottled water, but he ate fresh fruit that might have been washed with water from the local well. He states that he does not have fevers or chills but that he has lost a few kilograms of body weight.
His vital signs are within normal limits. There is mild tenderness to palpation in his lower abdomen.
A stool sample is sent for diagnostic studies, and the Giardia antigen test returns positive.
Which one of the following treatments is most likely to be appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Quinacrine is a second-line agent for treating Giardia infection and is no longer available for routine use.

B) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin, azithromycin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole are not effective against Giardia infection.

C) CORRECT:

Giardiasis is caused by the ingestion of Giardia lamblia cysts found in contaminated water or food. The incubation period is 7 to 14 days, and illness can range from asymptomatic infection to chronic diarrhea. Common symptoms include diarrhea, abdominal cramps, bloating, foul-smelling stools, and flatulence. Chronic symptoms can also include anorexia, headaches, and weight loss.

Diagnosis of Giardia infection is made through direct examination of the stool for cysts or through antigen testing. First-line treatment for adults and most children consists of tinidazole or nitazoxanide. Metronidazole, the former first-line agent, is now considered a second-line agent because of concerns about increasing rates of resistance.

Key learning point: First-line therapy for Giardia infection consists of either tinidazole or nitazoxanide.

D) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin, azithromycin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole are not effective against Giardia infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin, azithromycin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole are not effective against Giardia infection.

questions.text:
A previously healthy, fully immunized 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with moderate dehydration that has resulted in metabolic acidosis. Her parents say she has had 2 to 3 days of foul-smelling, explosive, watery diarrhea that developed shortly after they returned from a visit with extended family in rural Guatemala.
The child appears ill and tired. She is afebrile. Her heart rate is 120 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 25 breaths per minute, and her blood pressure is 82/56 mm Hg. She has a mildly distended abdomen with mild tenderness but no rebound or guarding.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abdominal CT may reveal nonspecific inflammation in the bowel but would not lead to a diagnosis of G. intestinalis infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Flexible sigmoidoscopy with biopsy may show evidence of G. intestinalis infection, but it is not the preferred test because it is invasive.

C) INCORRECT:

Although a bacterial stool culture is indicated in an ill child with diarrhea, a specific culture for a rare pathogen such as Vibrio parahaemolyticus, an organism transmitted by ingestion of raw shellfish, is not appropriate in this setting.

D) CORRECT:

Giardiasis — a parasitic infection of the small intestine caused by Giardia intestinalis (formerly known as Giardia lamblia) — is most often acquired in endemic areas. The incubation period ranges from 1 day to 2 weeks, and symptoms can last up to 3 weeks. The clinical manifestations of G. intestinalis vary: Many infected children remain asymptomatic, and severe manifestations of infection are rare. The most typical symptoms of an acute G. intestinalis infection are watery, foul-smelling, greasy diarrhea accompanied by abdominal cramping, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss.

G. intestinalis is diagnosed via microscopic examination of the stool and by direct fluorescent antibody staining. Microscopic examination is performed on wet mounts, and direct fluorescent antibody staining is done to aid visualization. The most sensitive method of diagnosis is Giardia antigen detection by enzyme-linked immunosorbent analysis, which is both highly sensitive and highly specific. Repeated examination is often necessary because of intermittent shedding.

Treatment is recommended for all patients with symptomatic G. intestinalis infection and for asymptomatic patients who are at risk of transmitting the pathogen to immunocompromised household members. Treatment options for children include tinidazole, metronidazole, and nitazoxanide.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial diagnostic evaluation for a child with suspected Giardia intestinalis infection is microscopic stool evaluation and Giardia antigen detection.

E) INCORRECT:

Measuring a fibrinogen level is not diagnostic for parasitic infections. Fibrinogen, the substrate for fibrin clot formation, helps support platelet aggregation and wound healing.

questions.text:
An 8-year old boy with a history of seasonal allergies presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of watery diarrhea, intermittent nausea, occasional vomiting, and 2.3 kg of weight loss. His parents describe his stool as greasy and foul-smelling. He recently traveled to Mexico with his family on vacation, but the diarrhea did not start until he had been home for one week.
On examination, the patient has normal vital signs, appears thin, and is in no distress. He has diffuse mild tenderness to palpation of the abdomen.
Stool samples are sent, and the Giardia antigen test returns positive.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: A diet of bananas, rice, applesauce, and toast (BRAT)

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral vancomycin is a treatment for Clostridioides difficile infection, which is most commonly identified in hospitalized patients.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has giardiasis, an infection of the small intestine caused by Giardiaintestinalis (previously known as Giardia lamblia).

Giardiasis typically affects travelers who drink untreated water. Symptoms of acute infection include watery, foul-smelling, greasy diarrhea with abdominal cramping, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss. The incubation period ranges from 1 day to 2 weeks, and symptoms can last up to 3 weeks. The infection is diagnosed by antigen detection, which has higher sensitivity than microscopic examination of the stool.

All individuals with symptomatic giardiasis should be treated. In addition, all individuals with diarrhea should be excluded from school or day care until symptoms resolve and treatment is completed. Treatment options include a 3-day course of nitazoxanide, a single dose of tinidazole, or a 5- to 10-day course of metronidazole. Because metronidazole is not available in the U.S. in a suspension for children and would need to be prepared by a local pharmacy — and because it is sometimes unpalatable to children — clinicians should be aware of the other first-line antiprotozoal agents.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a patient with symptomatic giardiasis is nitazoxanide for 3 days or a single dose of tinidazole.

C) INCORRECT:

Loperamide is an opioid-receptor agonist that reduces intestinal luminal motility. The delay in transit time has been shown to prolong bacterial diarrheas and is thought to play a role in prolongation of all infectious diarrheas.

D) INCORRECT:

A diet of bananas, rice, applesauce, and toast (BRAT) may be appropriate in cases of viral gastroenteritis but is unnecessarily restrictive and provides suboptimal nutrition.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics are warranted for the treatment of moderate-to-severe travelers' diarrhea, which is characterized by fever, more than 4 daily stools, and blood, pus, or mucus in the stool. When antibiotic treatment is indicated, ciprofloxacin can result in resolution of diarrheal symptoms in adults within one day; however, because of concerns about the development of arthropathy with fluoroquinolones, azithromycin is the preferred drug for travelers' diarrhea in the pediatric population.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a 5-day history of crampy abdominal pain and diarrhea. During this time, he has had 4–6 soft, voluminous, frothy bowel movements per day. Since the initial onset of his symptoms, he has also experienced fatigue, bloating, flatulence, and nausea. Nine days ago, he returned from a 2-week hiking trip in Colorado during which he drank water from a mountain stream. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 134/85 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation; bowel sounds are increased. A stool specimen shows no leukocytes. A fecal occult blood test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abdominal pain and watery diarrhea are symptoms seen in salmonellosis. Infection with Salmonella also commonly manifests with fever and severe vomiting, both of which are absent in this patient. Moreover, Salmonella is transmitted by the consumption of contaminated food products (notably poultry, raw eggs, and unpasteurized dairy), as opposed to drinking contaminated water from a mountain stream. Finally, this patient's bloating and flatulence are not consistent with salmonellosis, suggesting another etiology for his diarrhea.

B) CORRECT:

Frothy, nonbloody diarrhea with crampy abdominal pain and bloating in an afebrile individual with a history of drinking water from a mountain stream is consistent with giardiasis. Ingesting cysts from contaminated water sources (e.g., lakes, rivers, ponds, swimming pools) can cause infection with Giardia lamblia. Giardiasis impairs absorption within the gastrointestinal tract, leading to foul-smelling, greasy, and frothy diarrhea.

Common infectious causes of nonbloody diarrhea include bacteria (e.g., enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli, Clostridium perfringens, Clostridium difficile, Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus cereus, Vibrio cholera), parasites (e.g., Giardia, Cryptosporidium, Cyclospora), and viruses (Norovirus, Rotavirus). However, presentation with steatorrhea narrows the differential down to giardiasis.

C) INCORRECT:

This 25-year-old patient presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea, both of which are seen in Rotavirus gastroenteritis. However, Rotavirus infection also commonly manifests with fever and vomiting, which are not seen here. Moreover, this patient reports bloating and frothy diarrhea, both of which are inconsistent with Rotavirus infection. Furthermore, Rotavirus is transmitted through the fecal-oral route (e.g., by contact with hands, objects, food, water contaminated with the virus), rather than drinking water from mountain streams.

D) INCORRECT:

Intestinal amebiasis can also manifest with abdominal pain and diarrhea; however, diarrhea associated with intestinal amebiasis is bloody with mucus, unlike this patient's frothy, nonbloody diarrhea. In addition, intestinal amebiasis also commonly manifests with painful defecation, tenesmus, anorexia, and weight loss, which are not seen here. Moreover, amebiasis is rare in the US and most commonly associated with ingesting food or water contaminated by amebic cysts, especially in tropical and subtropical regions (e.g., Mexico, Southeast Asia, India).

E) INCORRECT:

Hookworm infection can manifest with abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, this patient lacks other characteristic features of infection such as pruritus, erythema, maculopapular rash, and serpiginous marks indicating the site of cutaneous entry. Moreover, hookworm is most commonly transmitted from walking barefoot over contaminated sand/soil, which is not consistent with this patient's history.
questions.hint: All of these pathogens can cause acute diarrhea. But only one of them typically presents with frothy, nonbloody diarrhea and is commonly acquired through consumption of untreated water such as mountain streams.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-day history of diarrhea, bloating, nausea, and vomiting. He describes his stool as soft, frothy, and greasy. He denies seeing blood in the stool. He went on a hiking trip last week and drank fresh water from the stream. Three months ago, he was on vacation with his family for 2 weeks in Brazil, where he tried many traditional dishes. He also had watery diarrhea and stomach cramping for 3 days during his visit there. The patient appears dehydrated. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). Examination shows dry mucous membranes and diffuse abdominal tenderness. Microscopy of the stool reveals cysts. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin can be used to treat traveler's diarrhea caused by enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli endemic in many tropical countries. This patient visited Brazil 3 months ago and might have contracted traveler's diarrhea (watery diarrhea) during that time, which resolved without further treatment. At this time, however, the patient most likely has giardiasis, which ciprofloxacin is not effective against.

B) CORRECT:

Giardiasis is the most common parasitic cause of diarrhea in the US. It is caused by Giardia lamblia, which can be transmitted by drinking contaminated untreated water (natural springs, streams). Tinidazole is an antibiotic that is effective against anaerobes and protozoa, and it is commonly used for the treatment of giardiasis. This treatment option has been shown to have fewer side effects, higher cure rates, and a lower antibiotic resistance rate than metronidazole, which is also frequently used to treat giardiasis in the US. Management also includes supportive care (e.g., hydration, electrolyte imbalance correction).

C) INCORRECT:

TMP/SMX is used for maintenance therapy in Whipple disease, which may also present with malabsorption and greasy stools. However, there are usually also extraintestinal symptoms such as migratory arthritis, lymphadenopathy, and/or neurologic deficits. Moreover, Whipple disease would not present with cysts in a stool sample. TMP/SMX is not effective against giardiasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral vancomycin is the first-line therapy for Clostridioides difficile infection, which may present with watery, rather than frothy and greasy, diarrhea. Moreover, C. difficile mainly causes infections in older patients (> 65 years) who have received treatment with an antibiotic like clindamycin or cephalosporin. This patient has no history of prior antibiotic treatment and most likely has giardiasis, which vancomycin is not effective against.

E) INCORRECT:

Supportive treatment is important in the context of diarrhea to replace fluid and electrolyte losses. However, this patient's diarrhea is caused by a parasite and therefore also demands causative treatment.
questions.hint: This patient's recent hiking trip, during which time he drank from a stream, and the detection of cysts in his stool make giardiasis the most likely diagnosis. This infection impairs absorption, which leads to greasy and frothy diarrhea.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man presents with a 2-week history of watery, foul-smelling diarrhea, mild abdominal cramps, and a 2-kg weight loss to the clinic. He recently returned from a backpacking trip in a mountainous region, where he frequently consumed untreated stream water. He denies any significant past medical history and has tried over-the-counter anti-diarrheal agents without relief. Vital signs are stable. Physical examination reveals mild abdominal distension without rebound tenderness. Laboratory results show a normal complete blood count and normal serum electrolytes. Stool analysis reveals no visible blood, and stool cultures for common bacterial pathogens are pending. He has not experienced fever or severe abdominal pain.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amebiasis, caused by Entamoeba histolytica, is associated with waterborne transmission but typically presents with dysentery, including bloody or mucoid stools, and systemic symptoms like fever or severe abdominal pain. The patient's symptoms of chronic watery, foul-smelling diarrhea and weight loss, without blood in the stool or systemic symptoms, do not match amebiasis. Additionally, amebiasis is more common in tropical regions, not mountainous areas.

B) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a functional gastrointestinal disorder with chronic abdominal pain and altered bowel habits, developing over a longer period. The acute onset of symptoms over 2 weeks, recent travel, and ingestion of untreated water do not fit IBS. Additionally, IBS is not typically associated with significant weight loss or foul-smelling, watery stools, which suggest malabsorption or infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryptosporidiosis, a waterborne protozoal infection, can cause watery diarrhea. However, in immunocompetent individuals, it is usually self-limited and lacks a pronounced malabsorptive component. The foul-smelling diarrhea and weight loss suggest malabsorption, which is less characteristic of cryptosporidiosis. The patient's normal laboratory values and lack of immunosuppressive conditions further differentiate it from cryptosporidiosis.

D) CORRECT:

Giardiasis is an intestinal infection caused by the protozoan Giardia lamblia, often acquired through ingestion of contaminated water. The patient's history of consuming untreated stream water during a backpacking trip, along with symptoms of watery, foul-smelling diarrhea and weight loss, aligns with giardiasis. The malabsorption symptoms, such as steatorrhea, explain the odor and weight loss. Giardia lamblia attaches to the small intestine's mucosa, disrupting normal absorption and causing gastrointestinal symptoms. The absence of fever or severe abdominal pain, combined with the travel history, supports the diagnosis of giardiasis.

Key learning point: Giardia lamblia infection is characterized by watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and weight loss, and is diagnosed by identifying trophozoites or cysts in stool or duodenal aspirates.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents with three weeks of persistent, foul-smelling watery diarrhea and a 5-kg weight loss. He recently returned from a hiking trip in a remote mountainous region. He reports bloating, mild abdominal cramping, and no fever. He denies significant past medical history or medication use. Initial stool studies, including tests for common parasites, are unrevealing. He has not improved despite empirical antibiotics.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tropical sprue manifests with chronic diarrhea and malabsorption but typically occurs in individuals in tropical climates, not mountainous regions. The recent hiking trip does not align with tropical sprue's endemic exposure. Additionally, tropical sprue often requires prolonged antibiotic therapy, which contrasts with the lack of response to empirical antibiotics here.

B) CORRECT:

Giardiasis, caused by Giardia lamblia, manifests with persistent, foul-smelling, watery diarrhea, weight loss, and bloating due to malabsorption. The patient's recent hiking trip suggests exposure to contaminated water, a common risk factor for giardiasis. Giardia cysts are resistant and can be ingested during outdoor activities, leading to infection. Negative initial stool studies may occur due to intermittent parasite shedding, necessitating multiple stool examinations or antigen detection assays for diagnosis. The non-inflammatory diarrhea, absence of fever, and lack of response to antibiotics align with a parasitic infection rather than bacterial or inflammatory causes.

Key learning point: Giardiasis is a common cause of persistent watery diarrhea and weight loss in travelers returning from areas with poor sanitation, and it may not always be detected in routine stool tests.

C) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) presents with abdominal pain, bloating, and altered bowel habits but is not associated with significant weight loss or foul-smelling diarrhea. The substantial weight loss and malodorous stool suggest a malabsorptive or infectious process. IBS typically has a chronic course, not a persistent presentation unresponsive to antibiotics.

D) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease presents with bloating, diarrhea, and weight loss, but its onset is typically insidious and linked to chronic gluten exposure, not recent travel. The acute onset following a hiking trip and the lack of systemic symptoms like fever suggest an infectious etiology. The failure to respond to antibiotics and negative stool studies point to a parasitic cause, not celiac disease.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents to the clinic with a week of daily watery, foul-smelling diarrhea, abdominal bloating, and mild epigastric pain. He reports passing up to five loose stools per day. He recently returned from a backpacking trip in Southeast Asia. He denies fever, chills, or blood in his stools. He has no known drug allergies and is not taking any medications. Physical examination reveals mild abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding. Basic metabolic panel results are normal (see report).
Stool microscopy: Motile trophozoites with a distinctive pear-shaped appearance
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for his condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Giardiasis, caused by the protozoan Giardia lamblia, manifests with watery, foul-smelling diarrhea, abdominal bloating, and mild epigastric pain, often following travel to endemic areas. Stool microscopy revealing motile trophozoites with a pear-shaped appearance confirms the diagnosis. Tinidazol is the first-line treatment due to its efficacy against anaerobic organisms and protozoa. It undergoes nitro-reduction within microbial cells, forming reactive intermediates that damage DNA and inhibit nucleic acid synthesis, leading to parasitic cell death. Tinidazole is preferred due to high cure rates and fewer side effects than metronidazole, which is a second-line treatment option.

Key learning point: Tinidazol is the treatment of choice for giardiasis, a common protozoan infection in travelers to endemic areas, characterized by symptoms such as watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps.

B) INCORRECT:

Albendazole inhibits microtubule polymerization and is effective against helminths, such as nematodes and cestodes. However, the stool microscopy findings of motile trophozoites with a pear-shaped appearance indicate a protozoan infection, not a helminthic one. Albendazole's mechanism does not target protozoa, making it inappropriate for treating giardiasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim sulfamethoxazole inhibits folate synthesis and is used for bacterial infections and some parasitic infections in immunocompromised patients. However, it is ineffective against Giardia lamblia, as the protozoan's metabolic pathways are not susceptible to folate antagonism. The stool findings confirm a protozoan infection, not bacterial diarrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Paromomycin, an aminoglycoside, is effective for luminal infections due to minimal systemic absorption. However, Giardia lamblia colonizes the mucosal surface of the small intestine, requiring systemically absorbed agents for effective treatment. Paromomycin is suboptimal for non-pregnant patients with symptomatic giardiasis.

questions.text: A daycare center notes multiple children with foul-smelling diarrhea. What measure most effectively reduces additional cases?

choices.text: Implementation of a giardiasis vaccine for all children
Metronidazole prophylaxis for all exposed children
Frequent hand washing with soap and water

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

No vaccine for Giardia lamblia exists for humans. While vaccination is effective for many diseases, giardiasis prevention relies on sanitation, hand hygiene, and environmental cleaning. Outbreak control involves frequent handwashing, disinfecting shared items, and adhering to infection control guidelines, not immunization.

B) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulins provide passive immunity for certain viral exposures but are ineffective against enteric protozoa like Giardia. They do not reach adequate gut concentrations to interrupt fecal-oral transmission. Established infection control measures, such as hand hygiene and environmental decontamination, directly address transmission routes.

C) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole treats symptomatic giardiasis but is not recommended for prophylaxis in exposed children. Outbreak control focuses on hygiene and environmental sanitation, not antibiotics for asymptomatic individuals. Prophylactic metronidazole poses risks, such as adverse effects and gut flora disruption, without addressing contamination sources or transmission modes.

D) CORRECT:

Giardiasis is transmitted via the fecal-oral route, with Giardia lamblia cysts being environmentally stable. Frequent hand washing with soap and water effectively removes these cysts, reducing ingestion risk. This practice is crucial in daycare centers, where close contact and lower hygiene levels are common. Soap aids in breaking down the protozoan's lipid structure, enhancing contaminant removal. Hand hygiene is a cornerstone of public health strategies to prevent enteric infections, making it essential in controlling outbreaks in high-risk environments.

Key learning point: Proper hand washing is the best and simplest way to prevent giardiasis infection by removing the parasite from the hands and reducing transmission risk.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, who works as an engineer, presents with a 4-day history of abdominal cramping and fatty, foul-smelling, nonbloody diarrhea. She returned from a business trip to Honduras 2 weeks ago. Her vital signs are normal, and she appears well hydrated. Stool microscopy is pending. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin can be used to treat Campylobacter enteritis, but it lacks efficacy in treating giardiasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used to treat yeast infections and other fungal diseases, but is not first-line for treatment of giardiasis.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Tinidazole is the preferred first-line antibiotic treatment for giardiasis because it has a high cure rate and fewer side effects than the alternatives.

D) INCORRECT:

TMP/SMX is the treatment of choice for cystoisosporiasis, but it lacks efficacy in treating giardiasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin is used for treating bacterial enteritis, particularly traveler's diarrhea caused by organisms like Salmonella or Campylobacter, but it lacks efficacy in treating giardiasis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with an 11-day history of abdominal cramping, bloating, and loose stools. She reports her stools are voluminous and malodorous but denies fever or blood. She is mildly nauseated but has not vomited and is eating and drinking normally. She returned 4 weeks ago from a cross-country road trip to collect her new puppy from a breeder. En route she visited several cities, spent 3 days camping in the backcountry, and went whitewater rafting. Physical examination shows mild abdominal tenderness and normal vital signs. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Direct fluorescent antibody testing of stool
CT scan of abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy with biopsy is invasive and unnecessary for this patient's presentation. The patient's symptoms and exposure history suggest infectious diarrhea that can be diagnosed with stool testing rather than endoscopic evaluation.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Direct fluorescent antibody testing is the gold standard for diagnosing giardiasis. The patient's presentation with malodorous, voluminous stools, abdominal cramping, and recent backcountry camping exposure strongly suggests Giardia infection. This test provides rapid and accurate diagnosis to guide appropriate antibiotic therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Empirical antibiotic therapy with ciprofloxacin targets bacterial pathogens but is not appropriate for parasitic infections. This patient's clinical presentation and exposure history warrant specific testing for Giardia before initiating targeted antiparasitic therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

While supportive care is important, this patient's characteristic presentation warrants specific diagnostic testing and likely treatment. Supportive care alone does not address the underlying parasitic infection.

E) INCORRECT:

CT imaging is excessive for this patient's clinical presentation. This patient has mild-to-moderate symptoms without fever, bloody stools, or signs of sepsis, making advanced imaging unnecessary when another test can provide the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with 4 days of cramping abdominal pain and diarrhea after a multi-day backpacking trip in Colorado. The patient reports drinking from mountain streams during the trip and describes their stool as voluminous, foul-smelling, and greasy. The patient does not have a fever or blood in the stool. What is the most appropriate test to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Stool antigen testing using direct fluorescent antibody testing is the gold standard for diagnosing giardiasis. This test uses microscopic detection of Giardia antigens in stool with immunofluorescence and provides rapid, accurate results. Up to 3 stool samples over several days can increase diagnostic sensitivity if initial testing is negative.

B) INCORRECT:

Gastroduodenoscopy can confirm the diagnosis if trophozoites are detected in duodenal fluids, but it is usually only performed if stool diagnostics are negative.

C) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures are not indicated for this patient's clinical presentation. This patient has normal vital signs without fever or signs of systemic illness, making blood cultures unnecessary for a localized gastrointestinal infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum antibody testing is not the standard diagnostic method for giardiasis. The diagnosis relies on direct detection of the organism or its antigens in stool samples.

E) INCORRECT:

Stool culture is designed to identify bacterial pathogens and will not detect Giardia, which is a protozoan parasite. This patient's clinical presentation of fatty, nonbloody stools after exposure to contaminated water sources suggests parasitic rather than bacterial infection.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a 5-day history of foul-smelling, voluminous diarrhea with abdominal cramps and bloating after drinking from natural water sources during a recent camping trip. She is afebrile with stable vital signs and mild dehydration. Stool microscopy shows multinucleated trophozoites consistent with a parasitic infection. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin is used for bacterial gastroenteritis, not parasitic infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is a second-line antibiotic for this patient's condition. Another antibiotic is preferred due to higher cure rates and fewer adverse effects.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Tinidazole is the preferred first-line treatment for giardiasis due to high cure rates and fewer side effects than metronidazole. The presence of multinucleated trophozoites in stool confirms the diagnosis, and immediate antibiotic therapy is indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Mebendazole is an anthelmintic effective against intestinal roundworms, hookworms, and other helminths. This medication is not recommended for this patient's infection.

E) INCORRECT:

While oral rehydration is important, supportive care alone is insufficient for symptomatic giardiasis. Antibiotic therapy is indicated for symptomatic patients with confirmed parasitic infection.
